keyTakeAways: A steel cable on the Glória funicular in Lisbon snapped shortly after operation began, leading to a deadly crash that killed at least 16 people and injured several others.
The cable failed to meet certification standards set by CARRIS, the funicular’s operator, and did not meet the operator’s own specifications.

The preliminary investigation by the Office for the Prevention and Investigation of Accidents in Civil Aviation and Rail (GPIAAF) identified serious failures in cable integrity, maintenance practices, and brake function.
Maintenance records show tasks were marked as completed even when not actually performed, and the maintenance plan was falsely recorded as 'compliant and accepted'.
Eyewitnesses described the incident as chaotic and uncontrolled, with one man, Bruno, describing the car as 'completely out of control' and likening it to a toy being thrown across the street.
A final report from GPIAAF will be released next year, and current findings are described as preliminary and not conclusive.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A fatal crash on the Glória funicular in Lisbon, Portugal, in September 2025, resulted in at least 16 deaths and multiple injuries when a steel cable snapped during operation. Preliminary findings by the Office for the Prevention and Investigation of Accidents in Civil Aviation and Rail (GPIAAF) reveal that the cable failed to meet safety specifications set by the operator, CARRIS, and that maintenance records were falsified, with tasks marked as completed even when not performed. Eyewitnesses, including a man named Bruno, described the derailment as sudden and uncontrollable. The investigation highlights systemic failures in cable integrity, maintenance, and safety protocols, raising concerns about infrastructure regulation. A final report is expected next year.
title: Cable in deadly Portugal funicular crash failed to meet specifications, preliminary report finds
